INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that I will be attending a Presiding Officers and Clerks conference in Darwin and will be away from Canberra from 19 to 26 June 1994. I will be absent from the sittings of the Senate for the period 20 to 23 June. Pursuant to standing order 13, I suggest that the Deputy President, Senator Crichton-Browne, be empowered to act as President during my absence.

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Schacht)—by leave—agreed to:

INTERJECT.PARA: (1)That, during the absence of the President, the Deputy President shall, on each sitting day, take the Chair of the Senate and may, during such absence, perform the duties and exercise the authority of the President in relation to all proceedings of the Senate and proceedings of committees to which the President is appointed.
(2)That the President be granted leave of absence for the period from 20 to 23 June 1994 inclusive.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth
That the majority of Australians clearly stand united in satisfaction with their existing Australian National Flag which reflects their values, history and heritage.
And that they condemn unwarranted attacks on their historic Australian Flag, whenever or wherever made by any Australian citizens.

So therefore do we call upon the Senate to ensure that the Australian National Flag, as publicly acclaimed in 1901 and confirmed under the Flags Act (1953), is not changed, replaced or diminished at any time, or in any manner whatsoever, without such a proposal being first voted upon and approved by a majority of Australian citizens in a national referendum.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Road Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned show:
We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that the current arrangements for federal road funding discriminate savagely against Victoria.

PARA.TAB: Victorians contribute about 27% of federal fuel excise revenues
More than 27% of freight movements occur on Victorian roads

PETITION.PARA: However, Victoria over the last decade has received less than 20% of total funds available. This means that major investment funds are not available to upgrade deficient roads and create an efficient road network.
The Federal Government ensure that Victoria receives its fair share of funding for existing and proposed national highways—at least $220 million in the next financial year.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes:

TAB.TAB: (i)the latest International Wool Secretariat study which shows that China was the world's leading customer for raw wool for the first time in 1993, with demand amounting to about 20 per cent of world production, and
(ii)that about two-thirds of wool used in China is imported, with Australian supplies accounting for 50 per cent of total imports;

PARA.TAB: (b)recognises that Australia produces between 75 and 80 per cent of the world's total tradeable wool;

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:
