DEBATE.TITLE: APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL 1994-95APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 1) 1994-95APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 2) 1994-95LOAN BILL 1994

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, when my contribution to this debate on the appropriation bills was interrupted earlier today, I was discussing how remarkable it is that this government can make economic forecasts buoyed by nothing but its own hot air, because that is exactly what we have seen. We have seen forecast after forecast which, if pricked with a pin, would burst in our faces like hot air balloons.

PARA.TAB: In its white paper on unemployment, the government predicted that economic growth between now and the end of the decade would average 4 3/4 per cent. Yet only one week later the same government is telling us that at no point in the next four years would economic growth exceed 4 1/2 per cent. Even Senator Burns on the other side of the chamber would have to understand—

TALK.START.PARA: —Four and a half is not bad.

—Four and a half this year, 4 1/4 next year, and four per cent for the next two years—if Senator Burns can add that up, divide it by four and get it to equal 4 3/4 per cent, which is exactly what his government said economic growth would average from now to the end of the decade, he is a better man than I am, Gunga Din. It does not work; it does not figure out.

PARA.TAB: Those opposite can have all the glib answers they like but, at the end of the day, they cannot defy the natural rules of mathematics. The natural rules of mathematics are that 4 1/2, plus 4 1/4, plus four, plus four, divided by four does not equal 4 3/4 per cent. Even the government's own backbenchers must be embarrassed by that one. That is how appalling this government's economic forecasting has been.

These are the same people who told us not to worry about foreign debt because it is `only' $210 billion. I hasten to add that that is more than the foreign debt of just about any other country in the world with the exception of the United States, which has 17 times our population and about five times the foreign debt. But these people say, `Don't worry, you can trust us with the economy'.

Mr Deputy President, let me put a few facts on the record. At $210 billion, foreign debt in this country exceeds the foreign debt of Chile, Mexico, Argentina, Venezuela, or any other Latin American country anyone might wish to name. Yet the government seems to make light of this fact. On this side of the chamber we do not make light of the fact that this government is compromising our economic sovereignty.

On behalf of the National Party—I am sure that my Liberal Party colleagues agree—I am happy to say that we support the statement made yesterday by the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Downer, when he said that the coalition in government would not sell the farm and would not compromise this nation's economic integrity.

Those on the other side are pawnbrokers—that is what they are, Australia's new pawnbrokers. They pawn this country to foreign interests, they grovel to the President of France, and all the while they are telling us not to worry about Australia's foreign debt.

This bunch of snivelling apologists for their own failed economic policies do not deserve to be heard on this matter. This bunch of snivelling apologists on the other side have sold this nation short for too long. It is a shame that this debate only affords me 20 minutes because it means that I have to let Senator Ray and Senator Burns off a good scolding for what they have done to the state of Queensland. But the state of Australia is a parlous one, and this government has contributed—no, not contributed, this government has manufactured—the very problems with which Australia is saddled today.

Worse still, this government has not just created problems for us here and now; this government has created problems for future generations of Australians who will sit in this place. Twenty years, 30 years, 40 years hence, when all of us have left this chamber, there will be another two or three generations of Australians grappling with the economic catastrophe that Labor has wreaked upon this country. That is the legacy we leave. It is not a legacy that can be fixed now; it is not a legacy that can be fixed in five years; but a legacy which will haunt future generations of Australians.

That is why those of us on this side say that enough is enough. We say that we are not going to compromise this nation's economic sovereignty. We say that we do not believe it is acceptable that our current account deficit should be $18 billion. We do not believe that $18 billion a year should leave the shores of our country and go into the coffers of foreign bankers overseas and the government not be worried about it. We do not believe that that $18 billion which could create however many hundreds of thousands of Australian jobs is not an issue. We believe it is the major issue. We believe that foreign debt will continue to be a major issue. We believe that this government is contemptible in its economic mismanagement of this country and ought to be condemned by every generation of Australians which will have to live with the consequences of its mismanagement of our economy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on Appropriation Bill (No. 2) 1994-95. It is a pleasure to follow my colleague Senator O'Chee in this debate. Senator O'Chee referred to foreign debt and quoted figures for Latin American states. I would like to compare it with another country. There is one country in this world that has had about 53 governments in 47 years at the last count, and there is no prize for guessing—
—Not us; we have had 57 oppositions in the last 11 years.

—Perhaps Senator Ray could give me a run at making my speech, as I generally let the Acting Prime Minister do. Mr Deputy President, are you going to stop that crossfire or do I have to take a point of order?

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)—Order!

TALK.START.PARA: —The country with 53 governments at the last count is not in Latin America; it is a place called Italy. Italy does not have a credit, but its foreign debt is nil. Every time I go to Italy no-one seems to be working, but the situation is that it has a nil foreign debt balance. Senator Ray says that we have a stable government, but we have this massive foreign debt. Let us get back to the appropriation bill.

PARA.TAB: I wish to address what has been left out of the appropriation bill rather than what is in it. The rural and remote regions of Australia are the ones that are not very well included in this bill. The highest order of scale of neglect in this appropriation bill is in road funding. If we listen to the Minister for Transport, Mr Brereton, and look at his press release, we would not think that there were any omissions. I will get back to him later.

TALK.START.PARA: —New South Wales put it into consolidated revenue.

—When the turn of Senator Neal—in brackets Della Bosca—comes, I will listen. We have a good relationship; I thought I would point that out to the rest of Australia. When Senator Neal comes to deliver her speech I will certainly listen to what she has to say. The areas which must have better roads and rail—and I will come back to rail in due course—for transporting rural produce and mineral produce are the places that have really missed out.

PARA.TAB: It goes without saying that for the sake of safety it is important that we have safe and better roads. The black spot program has been removed. I know it is a sunset clause. If it was a good program it should have been kept going. In this appropriation bill the federal government has allocated $820 million in 1994-95 to `improve' Australia's national highways. That is half of the amount that was spent in 1992-93, and it is less than the $850 that was allocated in the budget of the last Fraser government. That $850 million has not even been converted to real terms.

So we are $30 million below the last Fraser budget allocation. That is a total disgrace. We have increasing population and increasing mineral and rural production. That increase in production has nothing to do with this government. This government has tried to reduce production. The Left movement of the government is trying to cut down mineral production.

In the last year of the Fraser government 62.38 per cent of fuel excise went into roads. Out of the current appropriation only 8.54 per cent of fuel excise is going back into roads. Looking at the situation in Western Australia, I have a chart here from the budget papers. In 1980-81 the excise was $925 million, and 67.89 per cent went into roads. In 1982-93, the year of the last Fraser budget, it was still 62.38. In 1994-95 the projection shows that it goes down. Out of this appropriation it is 8.45 per cent for this year, for next year it is 8.10, for 1996-97 it is 7.79, and for 1997-98 it is 7.51. This shows us the attention that this

SPEECH.PARA: government is giving to roads. I seek leave to have this chart incorporated in Hansard after the minister has had a look at it.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The chart read as follows—

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is the $9.7 billion that is being raised in fuel excise at the present moment? In 1997 the projection is that it will rise to $11.54 million. Where is it going? A lot of it is going into misdirected government programs. I can tell you, Mr Deputy President, it is not going on roads. In his press release of 3 June Mr Brereton said that the federal government will provide $822 million in 1994 to improve Australia's 18,500 kilometres ofighway. On top of that, Mr Brereton said that the government will provide $676 million of untied funding to assist the states.

PARA.TAB: And so he goes on. There then follows a breakdown of the funding allocations. Out of that $820 million, $444 million will be spent on construction works, with an emphasis on extra funding for a number of major projects already started. So at least half of the allocation will be spent on existing projects rather than new ones. Therefore, those sections of highways that are in a very bad condition—quite a few of which I know about—will not receive immediate attention.

Also out of that $820 million, $332 million will be spent on the maintenance of national highways. The press release notes that Australia has 18,500 kilometres of highways, which means that the allocation of $820 million works out at $17,945 per kilometre. To most people who are not experienced in the cost of road repair, that would seem a high figure. However, it must be remembered that the average Australian `black top' has an age slightly above 25 years, which means that Australia's highways are quickly approaching the end of their lives.

Once a new bitumen road is laid at a cost of $80,000 per kilometre, for 15 years one can expect an almost maintenance-free life, with the exception of edge maintenance; between 10 and 25 years one can expect that a reasonable level of maintenance would be needed; between 25 and 35 years a reasonably high level of maintenance, and after 35 years the road should be ripped up and replaced with a new one. So, if Australia's highways are around 25 years old, they are rapidly approaching the stage where they will need more money spent on them. In other words, new highways will have to be laid at a cost in excess of $80,000 per kilometre. So, an allocation of $17,945 per kilometre is nowhere near enough. Further, out of that $820 million, $44 million will be spent on administrative expenses et cetera.

I will just list the allocations for national highways. The back of the press release lists the allocation of this road money to the states and territories. It shows that New South Wales, represented by Senator Neal, will receive $328 million for its section of national highways, and untied funds of $97.63 million to local government—the greatest allocation of road funding in Australia. Next comes Victoria, with an allocation of $135 million. Yet only $58.13 million is allocated for Western Australia and $43.4 million in untied funds.

I repeat that Western Australia's untied funds are $43.4 million, yet the Western Australian Minister for Transport, the Hon. Eric Charlton, of the National Party, who comes from Tammin, said that the minimum need for Western Australia is $53 million. I have often spoken in this place about the Northam bypass. From my observation of the traffic around that area, Northam has needed such a bypass for more than 10 years. The minimum cost of that bypass is $30 million. So where would that $43 million go in a vast state like Western Australia which, it should be remembered, produces 25 per cent of Australia's export income. The state has been badly treated.

Western Australia is such a vast state that the $58 million that Mr Brereton has announced will have to be spent in areas remote from Perth. I am referring to projects such as development roads, road widening, bridge widening et cetera. Minimal funding is available for the wheat belt and the goldfields located 600 to 800 kilometres from Perth, which I would describe as being reasonably close to Perth. However, the money for those areas is most welcome. Recently, I drove from Kununurra to Halls Creek and back, and my colleague Senator Ellison drove from Broome to Halls Creek on the same day so that we could compare notes. But there is very little allocation for road funding in the areas of high population.

Mr Brereton went to inspect the Greenmount accident site. Two persons were killed and 21 cars wrecked in that horrific accident—and it could have been a lot worse. Mr Brereton said he would do something about the condition of that road. He has done something about it—he has said, `Take it out of this allocation.' He did the same with the Northam bypass. So this government has certainly neglected Australia's roads.

Earlier, I referred to the black spots program, initiated by Mr Bob Brown when he was Minister for Land Transport. This program targeted high accident areas and concentrated road spending on those areas. I admit that at the time I criticised the program because I thought it was a political stunt. I thought these black spots were located in marginal seats that the Labor government was trying to win. But I admit my mistake—it has turned out to be a top program, and I thought that the government would also have realised this and kept it going. However, for reasons best known to himself, Mr Keating terminated the program in 1993.

A black spot near Wooroloo in Western Australia has been fixed but, unfortunately, it claimed the life of a good friend. However, for every $500,000 spent on a black spot, a life is saved. Each road fatality costs Australia $631,000. It is estimated that the black spot program has saved 540 lives and $340,740,000. During its life, the black spot program cost only $270 million. With those figures in mind, I would like to know why the Keating government terminated the program. For every $1 million spent on roads, 61 person-years of employment are created, together with 25 jobs directly related to roads and 36 jobs in related industries such as manufacturing and transport.

The benefit of road construction is spread throughout the community in job creation. While that is obvious, when this spending was initially allocated I said that it would only go to recognised present-day contractors. But many times when such contractors go to an area to do a job, they tend to pick up local employment, which is good.

The road sector has the highest employment generating capacity of all sectors which produce a physical product of economic value. This is a key contribution to those rural areas. Only community service and public administration create more employment. Once again, why did Mr Keating cut this program? I know I said before, and the minister at the table interjected, that it had a sunset clause, but why did not the government look at it and keep it going?

As I mentioned earlier, fuel tax has a great effect on road transport, including long distance road transport, as well as rail. In its last budget, the Keating government put into action rises in fuel taxes which were to increase every six months. In August 1993 there was a rise of 3c per litre, which added $3,600 per rig per year. In February 1994, the price rose by a further 1c per litre, which added a further $1,200 per rig per year. In August 1994 there will be a further increase of 1c per litre, making $1,200 per rig per year. That total increase of 5c per litre will raise costs by $6,000 per rig per year. That is why people in the rural and remote areas suffer from this government's increases. The government has not done enough for rail or for the CSIRO in these appropriation bills. On behalf of Senator Short, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add: "but the Senate opposes the Government's decision to establish and allocate funds to the Aboriginal Land Fund and calls on the Government to direct more adequate funding towards aboriginal health, housing and education, and other social needs.".

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the opportunity in this debate on the appropriation bills to refer in particular to the new parenting allowance which the government announced in its white paper, confirmed in these budget papers and specifically provided for on page 3104. This measure is going to amount to $2.8 billion by the year 1997-98, so we are dealing with a very significant appropriation in relation to this new area.

PARA.TAB: The parenting allowance is, in principle, welcomed by us, but there are some factors which need to be pointed out before the government gets the opportunity to make unwarranted political mileage out of this particular measure. The most important thing to draw to people's attention is the fact that this measure does not apply until 1 July 1995. We must ask the question: why? It was announced with enormous gusto and bravado, it was an historic new payment which was going to change the world, but people will not get it until 14 months after its announcement. It does not take an undue degree of cynicism to think that the timing is very convenient for the government in relation to what is expected to be a mid- to late 1995 federal election.

Given the confirmation in the latest Time Morgan Gallup poll of attitudes to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) among females, I am not surprised at the timing. He is probably the most unpopular Prime Minister among female voters that we have ever had; some 60 per cent disapprove of him. So the government has a major problem among women with its Prime Minister, many of whom would probably like him removed before the next election. So this is a measure which will satisfy the electoral timetable as well.

The parenting allowance, to the extent that it is paid over and above the home child-care allowance, only applies to the poorest five per cent of Australian families with children. It is only going to go, on the government's best estimates, to 120,000 families with children out of a total of two million families with children. We need to remind ourselves of these great limitations on this payment before we all get carried away with it. It will apply in full up to a family income of $230 a week and cut out when the family income reaches $378 a week, which is well below average weekly earnings. So we are talking about a benefit which applies to the very poorest members of our community. While we welcome it, we have to remember that it is very limited in its scope and it is not something for which the government can be allowed to claim enormous electoral credit.

The other thing to remember when talking about this measure is that it is in part a switch of the unemployment benefit to the parenting allowance. Again, without being too cynical about it, the fact is the government is doing its utmost to switch as many people as possible from unemployment benefits to other forms of benefits so that they do not show up on the unemployment figures—`If you don't like the figures, change the way they are measured and you achieve your end.' There is a lot of fiddling going on with this particular benefit.

Most mothers who are sacrificing an income to care for their children at home are simply not going to get any additional benefit at all out of this parenting allowance. Their situation is not changed by this benefit. Most women who are at home caring for their children and who have sacrificed income to do so, will be left with what they have always had, and that is the dependent spouse rebate. The government has now changed its name, called it a home child-care allowance, and thrown in the equivalent of one hamburger per week to round it off to $30 a week. That is all most mothers will be left with, which is what they have always had.

As far as most women at home caring for children are concerned, this new dependent spouse rebate, renamed the home child-care allowance, is really nothing more than a bone thrown to those mothers as a consequence of the introduction of the child-care rebate. This raised with the government the enormous problem it had of equity in relation to mothers who were not in the paid work force but who were caring for their children at home. The white paper and the budget do absolutely nothing to end this government's discrimination against those mothers who are sacrificing an income to care for their children at home. The tragedy of this budget, the government's plans, the white paper and everything else, is that it is a huge, lost opportunity to address this very significant problem. There is a big problem of inequitable treatment of mothers in relation to whether they are at home or whether they are in the paid work force.

I noted recently that the responsible—or irresponsible—Minister for Family Services, Senator Crowley, seemed to have changed her language in relation to this matter. All of a sudden she has very noticeably started talking in terms that we have used for some time. She is now talking about fairness, equity and choice in relation to payments made by the government to families with young children. While we welcome her change of language, unfortunately it is not reflected in substance, and there is no change whatsoever in policy, and no indication that there is going to be any change in policy or recognition of the inequitable treatment of mothers at home caring for their children. Government policy is still very much biased against the choice of home care.

The government is putting out enormous and expensive carrots to mothers to enter the paid work force, and throwing raw bones to those who are sacrificing an income to remain at home. While we welcome Senator Crowley's change of rhetoric, we wish she would follow through in substance, change the policy, and get it right. The tragedy is that, under Labor, it is no longer politically correct to choose home care. Don Edgar, the well-known former director of the Australian Institute of Family Studies for many years, and one who would know, made the point publicly that policy in Canberra is driven by an outmoded feminist dogma which treats mothers who choose home care as poor, misguided fools. That is the reality of policy.

That was confirmed in a report that I saw yesterday from AAP. It was about a study, completed by a couple of Queensland professors and commissioned by the federal and state governments, of the contribution to the economy of mothers who sacrifice an income to remain at home. The report makes the point that their role `is largely unrecognised by the income support and taxation systems'. This report—as I said, commissioned by the federal and state governments—recommends that the federal government's new home child care rebate be renamed the home and dependent care rebate and be extended to anyone who is staying at home and caring for a person who needs ongoing care.

There is great controversy about the government's particular policy approach in this area, a lot of disagreement with the direction and a lot of recognition of the inequity of the scheme. The government has to face the fact that mothers at home caring for their children will not continue to be treated as second-class sisters. They have every right to demand equal treatment from this government. If this government takes money from people in the form of taxes, it has a responsibility to distribute it to citizens equitably and fairly and not use it to pursue particular political dogma, as it has been doing in this area.

There is no doubt that the government should assist mothers with young children—there is agreement about that—but it must not do so in a discriminatory and unfair way. That is the consequence of the current government policy. That is the consequence of the operation of the child-care tax rebate and of the home child-care allowance and it is not fixed up by the introduction of a parenting allowance. That does not solve the problem because, as I said, it applies only to the poorest five per cent of Australian families.

The child-care rebate, which was introduced with such fanfare but, of course, roundly criticised by former Labor Minister for Finance, Peter Walsh, is often justified by the government as some kind of legitimate tax deduction for working women—a tax rebate for the cost of caring for their children.

That is a superficially attractive argument and there are two points that I would like to make about it. If we pursue that line of logic, why not allow all working women to deduct all the costs necessarily incurred in them earning an income, including transport to and from work, all the clothes they use and all the housekeeping that they have to pay for because they are not home. The logic of the argument in relation to child care must, by definition, apply right across the board. But we see no attempt on the part of the government to do that, which suggests that there is a political motive in mind.

Of course, to defend the child-care tax rebate as it applies across the board—as Peter Walsh points out, very regressively—is to ignore equity for those mothers who sacrifice an income to stay at home to care for their children. It introduces a massive inequity in relation to their treatment. So that is an indefensible argument for the child-care tax rebate as brought in by this government.

That problem is not solved by changing the name of the dependent spouse rebate to a home child-care allowance, nor is it solved by introducing a parenting allowance. As I have said, the parenting allowance is welcome in principle, but the problem is—I pointed this out in a question to Senator Crowley recently—that we now have the most unbelievable smorgasbord of benefits which ordinary Australians have no hope of understanding. With the introduction of a parenting allowance we have that benefit on top of the child-care rebate, child-care assistance, home child-care allowance, basic family payment, additional family payment, and we look like having a maternity allowance added to all of them. It is the most unbelievable, complex system of benefits—a system, we believe, that the bureaucrats have deliberately designed as a make work scheme for them because it will take an army to work out who gets what and how. I pity the recipients, the supposed beneficiaries, of these schemes as they try to wade their way through it.

I understand that today Peter McDonald, from the Australian Institute of Family Studies, made the point publicly to Senator Crowley that this is a hopeless shemozzle of benefits that is way beyond the comprehension of most ordinary Australians. I make the point that the announced maternity allowance is just adding to the complexity of all of these schemes. I earnestly hope that if the government brings in a maternity allowance it treats all mothers equally. I hope that it pays the benefit to all mothers and does not use the maternity allowance as another form of government discrimination against mothers caring for their children at home.

In highlighting the incredible range of benefits washing around in the system, the point I want to make is that, as Peter McDonald of the Institute of Family Studies said today, the situation can be addressed only by the government facing up to the need for a single, simple, universal benefit. If we as a society honestly believe that mothers with young children need assistance, based on society's obligation to young children to have them brought up in a civilised and caring way, the only way to do that is to have a simple, universal benefit which everybody can understand and, most importantly, is fair. This will give mothers the choice they deserve as to whether they care for their children at home or whether they put their children into some form of child care, be it with grandparents, professional carers or whatever. That is a choice for mothers to make, not this government pursuing its political dogma.

While I welcome the fact that Senator Crowley is getting the rhetoric of choice right, I wish she would face up to this issue and look seriously at amalgamating this incredible range of complex benefits into a scheme that ordinary Australians will understand. I have advocated a universal benefit which should be based on certain criteria. It should be child based—that is, based on the number of children. It must be simple if Australians are to be able to work their way through it and get the maximum benefit out of it and if people are not to miss out. There must be equitable treatment of people and it must be universal. Without universality, people will miss out, it will be inequitable and there will be enormous wastage in bureaucrats administering the schemes.

I have put forward one way of doing that—a child tax credit or benefit which would be a flat amount paid to the primary carer, in most cases the mother, on the basis of the number of children and paid as either a tax credit or a benefit. As I have said before, if we look at the 1995-96 expenditure on assistance to families with children, we are talking about nearly $13,000 million in this area alone—that is ignoring unemployment benefits and all sorts of other benefits which some families receive.

In 1997-98, government spending in this area will rise to nearly $14,000 million. There are four million children aged 0 to 16, so a simple mathematical deduction gives us $3,250 per annum per child for every child in this country. That is a significant amount of money which, in fact, is the equivalent of what the government will be spending in the next couple of years.

It is very simple for this government to solve the incredible problem which it is getting itself into, and which people such as Martin Ferguson, Bettina Cass, Peter McDonald, Peter Walsh and a whole lot of people on the government's side of the fence are now starting to complain about. I am sure Labor members' offices are receiving plenty of complaints from constituents who have no idea what they are entitled to or how they get it, and, of course, the government is now having to spend millions and millions of taxpayers' dollars to try to explain all these benefits to ordinary Australians.

I urge the government to start looking at a universal system for assisting families with children. The government is starting to run the line that such an approach would be highly regressive and that the poorest members of the community would miss out. I reject that line. We are talking about the government's appropriation for assistance to families with children and how that should be fairly and equitably paid to ensure maximum choice for mothers in the care of their children.

Obviously it would be critical to ensure that in introducing such a scheme no-one was actually worse off. The poorest members of the community can be assisted through various other schemes. For example, unemployment benefits, rent assistance, and other things that are currently paid over and above the government's appropriation for assistance to families with children, can still be available based on poverty. We are talking about a scheme based on having young children, and the community has an obligation to assist carers of children to bring up their children.

The question of society's obligation to help the poorest members of the community is another question altogether. Our advocacy of a universal scheme does not detract from the obligation of society to help its poorest members and to ensure that the introduction of the sort of scheme I am talking about is not regressive and does not hurt our poorest members.

While welcoming the concept of the parenting allowance in principle, in my view the parenting allowance should really be a universal benefit paid regularly as a tax credit or benefit. It could all be done out of the tax system, as Daryl Dixon explained to us very succinctly. We do not need an army of bureaucrats to do it. We would save a fortune in administration, we would be able to help many more families, it would be much more equitable, and it would give real choice to mothers with young children.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in the second reading debate on the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1994-95 and related bills. I want to take the opportunity to comment on the government's budget and its running of the economy. This latest budget is a budget of missed opportunity. Who is likely to miss out? The people who are likely to miss out are the underclass in Australia. What do I mean by the underclass? Essentially, they are the about one million—or a little less now—unemployed and almost one million underemployed. So it is a very large proportion of the Australian community which is the underclass—and has been for the last two or three years.

PARA.TAB: The government attempted to address the problems of that underclass with its green and white papers on unemployment. But the programs that have come out of that white paper do very little for real jobs. What those programs are all about is trying to make unemployment palatable for the rest of the community. They are really bandaids, trying to cover over the real problems. They have done very little to encourage long-term sustained growth in the economy.

Even the government acknowledges that it is really only through strong economic growth that we will get sustained growth in jobs in Australia. The government does not even believe its own rhetoric that it has put out in the green and white papers. I will illustrate. In the green paper, which is the first paper it put out, it stressed the idea of economic growth encouraging growth in employment and, hence, reductions in unemployment. It canvassed two options for economic growth. The first option was at a growth rate between now and the rest of this decade of 3 1/2 per cent per annum. That would lead to a seven per cent rate of unemployment by the year 2000. That was the low growth option. The high growth option was at 4 3/4per cent per annum. If that was sustained right through to the year 2000, we would end up with an unemployment rate of about five per cent.

I might add that since this government has been in power, there have been only two years where there have been high growth rates of over five per cent; in 1983 with 5.3 per cent and in 1984 with 5.6 per cent. In spite of what the government said in the green paper and in spite of its rhetoric of adopting an objective of trying to achieve a five per cent target by the year 2000, what do we find in the budget papers? When we look at the budget papers, we find that the growth rate the government is assuming in this budget is 4 1/2 per cent for this coming financial year, 1994-95; 4 1/4 per cent for the following year; then four per cent for the next two years beyond that.

So already, in the space of just a few months, the government has shot itself in the foot with regard to unemployment and the underclass, basically by saying in its budget papers, `We do not believe the growth projections we optimistically put before the community a little earlier.' It would appear that there is very little chance of achieving its target of five per cent unemployment by the year 2000. Why has the government gone along this route? We have had the evidence from the Secretary to the Treasury that the high unemployment rate was basically a matter of choice. There is no doubt that this government took that low growth-high unemployment path as a matter of deliberate political choice.

This afternoon I want to canvass two major dimensions of this problem. The first is the government deficit and its relation to the interest rate regime in this country. The second matter I want to talk about is capital efficiency and investment within Australia

SPEECH.PARA: leading to long-term sustained jobs. Let us start with the budget deficits. The facts are that this government, by the end of this financial year—in other words, in a few weeks time—will have accumulated deficits at Commonwealth level of $38 billion since 1991-92. The projections in the budget papers indicate that by the end of the year 1996-97, that budget deficit will have grown to $64 billion. I remind the Senate and the community that, to put that into context, the GDP of Australia is somewhat over $400 billion. So we are talking about a very large slice of a year's activity that has been accumulated as debt by the federal government.

PARA.TAB: It would not be so bad if these deficits were spent on capital goods. Everyone who has run a household knows that we cannot go on spending more than we earn. But it is still sensible for a household to borrow to invest in capital goods, for instance to buy a house. As long as the interest and repayments are within the cash flow, people can cope with that. But here we have a government which has borrowed nearly $40 billion to date, and intends to borrow up to $64 billion over the next few years in accumulation over this period from 1991-92 through to 1996-97. Most of it will be spent on consumption; only a very small proportion is intended to be invested by the government.

Let us contrast that with what the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) said in the One Nation statement a little over two years ago, in February 1992, when he bragged that the government would have its budget in surplus by 1994-95. How come there has been a change of objectives from that surplus? I remind honourable senators that that was said at the time the FitzGerald report, commissioned by the government, made a plea for additional savings in Australia, to stop us borrowing more from overseas, and to save more.

The biggest culprit against savings was the spending—in other words, the deficits—by the federal government. All employer groups, most economic commentators and the coalition this year have been pushing the government to adopt a much faster rate of budget deficit reduction than it has done this year. The coalition suggested to the government that it ought to aim for a budget deficit of below $10 billion. Others were suggesting that it ought to be substantially less than that, given that there was a growth dividend coming out of the economy. The economy has been growing faster than was anticipated.

More importantly, it was suggested that we aim for surplus within a couple of years. But the government decided to spend up and to marginally reduce the deficit. In fact, the reduction in deficit is sort of hidden by asset sales. So again we are spending what was invested. In household terms, we are spending part of the house rather than reducing our expenditure. The net result of this will be a big impact on interest rates. Those interest rates will affect all Australians. Already the bond rate has gone up substantially—over two per cent. International bond rates have gone up, particularly as the American authorities took action to try to kill off any expectation of inflation.

In Australia the commentators are accusing the government of deliberately holding down short-term rates against the judgment of the market. Last week and this week we have had Syntec, Westpac and National Mutual making predictions that interest rates will go up between three and five per cent over the next year or so, which will impact on everybody.

So we have a government which has taken a deliberate route which will again encourage boom and bust. While the economy is running on quite smoothly now, the government has deliberately avoided the hard decisions of cutting expenditure and cutting the deficit, and hence taken the very substantial risk that we will head into boom-bust cycles once again. Who will miss out on this? Again, the underclass, because with each boom-bust cycle we ratchet up the base level of unemployment. The obvious message is that the government should have cut its expenditure and should have had a lower deficit. To illustrate what could have been done, it is important for the community to understand that real government expenditure by the federal government has increased by over 16 per cent—after allowing for inflation—over the last four years, including this current year, and is predicted to increase further by at least 3.1 per cent next financial year, even taking into account the sale of assets.

So we have had a real increase in expenditure by the federal government of over 20 per cent over a five-year period when the rest of Australians, be they state governments, government businesses or, more importantly, the 70 per cent of the community working in the private sector, have had to tighten their belts. What have we had here? We have had increased expenditure. So there is room for manoeuvring. Again, I stress that the message is that the deficit should have been lower, hence there would have been less risk of higher interest rates and less risk of a boom-bust cycle with the inevitable consequence for the underclass—the unemployed and the underemployed in Australia.

I move on to the second major topic with regard to the management of the economy, and that is capital efficiency and investment in Australia. I have said in this chamber many times that the investment in Australia of recent times is at its lowest level since World War II. Part of that investment, which is plant and equipment, has been running at around six per cent of GDP for nearly three years now. I stress that that is the lowest level since World War II.

We are all concerned as to why investment has not taken off here in Australia. Even with the economy growing quite well, how come there is no investment? One major reason why investment is not taking off yet has been put forward by Professor Helen Hughes. It is a very important point. Her point is that capital in Australia is being used only about 25 per cent of the time. In other words, on average, a lot of the equipment—the factories, the offices, the computers, the trucks, the rail cars, the ships—is being used only about 25 per cent of the time. Only a minority of businesses and activities in this country work full time—that is, 24 hours a day, seven days a week—largely characterised by the mining industry and some manufacturing industry, including the paper industry from which I came. As a general rule, there is very little double time and triple time working right around the clock in Australia.

Why is this the case? The largest problem is penalty rates. Penalty rates in awards stop businesses from using existing capital efficiently. In the past, the tariff protection made it worthwhile still investing. But now with international competition, as we have wound down protection and continue to wind down protection, which is the right thing to do, people can invest anywhere. Hence, investors are looking to invest not here in Australia where it is difficult to make a dollar because of this problem, but offshore.

We have only to look at examples all around us to see industries that do not work long hours. Take the construction industry, for instance; it is basically characterised in Australia as day shift only. Contrast that with our Asian neighbours just up the road. The blame for this waste of capital should really be laid at the feet of the unions and the ACTU. We will go on wasting capital in Australia unless we do something to break the nexus and encourage people to work.

We must free up the labour market. It is the critical decision that needs to be made. That can happen. In current circumstances large firms with sophisticated management understand the need to go through the complications of enterprise bargaining, as put up by the Brereton act. It is the small firms which characterise most of Australia that are in difficulty and do not want to go into those complications. They are the ones who are being penalised. They are the ones who foresee these penalty rates as stopping them expanding their businesses. That great amount of underutilised capital is a principal reason why we have not seen a boom in new investment, which we should have expected if this lift out of the recession had been typical of other recessions.

The net impact of this is again borne by the underclass—the unemployed and the underemployed. What do we have to do? We have to free up the labor market, free up the use of that existing bank of capital in Australia and encourage new investments. A few of these things are directly under government control. Ports and railways can be freed up by lowering the costs of government services. A report last week stated that the Port of Melbourne is now the second most expensive port in the world. There is a lot that can be done.

I think Australia can and will respond if given the opportunity. We have a huge consumer market to our north—two billion people, of which about 300 million today are on middle to high incomes. We can supply into such markets and work with them, but we have to remove the restrictions and allow Australians to get on with doing a good job and having high economic growth for our kids and their kids.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Sen A.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1994-95 and related bills. In doing so, I am conscious of my colleague Senator Gibson's statements about this being a budget of missed opportunities. I think many people in Australia, particularly those in rural Australia that I know, would also say that it is a budget that offers them very little hope—very little more hope than they had in the past, anyway. As a matter of fact, it could even be said that this budget has sent a fairly heartless message to many rural communities in Australia.

PARA.TAB: It seems to be saying that if people are temporarily poor through circumstances beyond their control, or if they are struggling, the option is to sell up and get out and move to the city or to some other major centre where they will probably have to be looked after by the government anyway. It seems pretty obvious to me that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and this government do not seem to care about those Australians, particularly in rural areas, who are struggling to battle their way out of a very tough recession and very tough economic circumstances which have hit them hard. The evidence is fairly crystal clear because Mr Keating, the Prime Minister, in his introduction to Working Nation said:

SPEECH.PARA: If we are to develop the strength to compete in the world and maintain and increase our standard of living, we must make the most of all our resources. Greatest of all these are the talents and energies of the Australian people. When we waste them we are weakened.

I could not agree more with the Prime Minister. I find it very sad that the talents and energies of so many Australians, who in many cases are deprived of resources, are wasted. But that statement is full of hypocrisy and contradictions because, really, what exactly is in this budget for rural Australians? I cannot see where it develops the strength of rural and regional people. I cannot see where it sees fit to make the most of their resources or to utilise their talents and energies.

PARA.TAB: Throughout the history of this nation many of the people who have used their energies and their talents to the fullest have been those people who have undergone many hardships in the past in developing land and producing export income for this great country. Those people have found themselves in only recent times under adverse circumstances going through exactly the same sorts of hardships that their forebears went through years and years ago. Sometimes I wonder whether the Prime Minister realises that country people are still Australians.

I would like to take this opportunity to set the Prime Minister and the government straight: rural people are hard working and, most importantly, they do not want handouts. They would like to be able to get by without handouts. I think their record over a long period has proved that they want to get by with their own devices and without any handouts. But their needs are similar to those of the rest of the community. All they want is equal access to basic services, such as health, education, transport, communications and community services.

It seems unfortunate that this government has turned its back on these people when they most need it and has swept many of their concerns under the economic carpet. In Working Nation, Mr Keating further enlightens us, saying:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . in declining regions . . . younger and more mobile members of the community leave to find employment elsewhere, they are not being replaced by people moving to the region.

We do not have to be Rhodes scholars to know that. Anybody who has moved around in rural communities in recent times would know the devastating effect that the depressed rural economy has had on communities right throughout Australia. The whole fabric and framework of those rural communities is being broken down, in some cases probably never to be restored.

PARA.TAB: The regions are certainly declining. Judging by the measures in this budget and previous budgets, the explanation is obvious: many farmers are leaving the land. The reason they are deserting the regions is that they are trying to escape the effect of not receiving any help when they need it the most. They feel, in many cases, that this federal government has turned its back on them.

Let us have a look in detail at the encouragement the government has given people to stay in those areas that are in a state of decline at present. This budget has seen drastic cuts to government spending on urban and regional development programs. Spending has been slashed from $332 million to $95 million, and next year it will be cut back to $71.5 million. But, no, the government did not stop there—that was not enough. It went on to cut back funding to the states, which in many ways probably play the most significant role in regional development. Such a flagrant disregard for people in rural areas is appalling.

Because of the isolation of many rural communities, taxes such as the fuel excise—we have been through this debate before—fall disproportionately on people who live long distances from major metropolitan areas. This government will raise the fuel tax on unleaded and diesel fuel by 1c per litre this August. This represents an overall increase of 5c per litre since last year. The cost to people living outside metropolitan areas is absolutely staggering, particularly through added freight costs.

What are the rural and regional communities getting out of these fuel tax hikes? Unfortunately, the answer is: not very much. In fact, in relation to those communities, the government has abolished funding for state arterial roads. This follows the termination of funding for local roads in 1991-92. Certainly I and the constituents whom I know best in country South Australia find this quite disgraceful. There are roads in country areas that are in urgent need of repair and, in some cases, poor road maintenance is not only costing delays in transport but is also costing lives.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not at Urania they don't.

—I do not know how long it has been since the minister has been to Urania but the roads certainly are not getting any better. Perhaps, if he goes back there, he will see that the cuts in funding in areas such as that are causing some difficulties.
—It must be the fault of the Liberal government in South Australia.

—No, the Liberal government has not been there long enough. I think it is the fault of a long period of Labor government; perhaps we should blame that government for it. Last year the government terminated the black spot program, a program which at the time was described by Bob Brown, the Minister for Land Transport in 1991, as being:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . one of the most outstanding programs for road safety that has ever been adopted by any government in Australia.

Black spot funding happens to save lives as well as money. It has been estimated by people other than me that every time there is a death on the road it costs the taxpayer something like $631,000. It has also been estimated that, for every $500,000 spent on black spot funding, a life was saved. People do not have to be students of economics to realise that the termination of the black spot program in taxpayer terms is actually costing money. It is not saving money; it is costing money. On top of that, the black spot program was also an important tool in job creation because each program put at least 25 people in jobs on the road and provided another estimated 36 jobs in the related manufacturing and transport industries.

PARA.TAB: I do not want to get back to an old chestnut but the diesel fuel rebate is another prime example of how the government not only ignores the needs of country people but also tries to hoodwink them. The government's claim of a $70 million increase in spending on rural and resource industries is dubious because the increase of $56 million in the diesel fuel rebate was included in that figure, money which off-road diesel fuel users already paid and were then entitled to receive as a rebate.

An increase in the diesel fuel rebate resulting from an increase in excise on diesel fuel should not be counted as an increase in expenditure. That is creative accounting at its very worst. The government is simply taking with one hand and giving it back with the other. I wonder whether the government really thought that it could get away with this sleight of hand.

In rural Australia fuel excise has a great impact on almost every facet of people's daily lives. In most cases rural people have to drive greater distances for normal services, such as visiting the doctor, grocery shopping, visiting friends and family, driving children to school and after school activities, and the list goes on. Rural families are complaining that they are becoming increasingly isolated because this government has cut or regionalised essential services. People who require these services the most—women, children and the elderly—have difficulty accessing them partly because of the added cost of fuel and the added cost of transport.

As a matter of fact there are also many who, in the most depressed circumstances, say they are finding it difficult to afford telephoning for information advice because, as the Senate would be aware, nearly every call that is made is at STD rates. For those on a very tight budget, in these economic circumstances even an STD telephone call for information can make a dramatic impact on their household budget.

Life is getting tougher and lonelier for those people who are hard hit by the rural crisis. Some women say that they have been asked by their husbands to stay at home and to avoid making too many telephone calls because of the expense. Who would have thought three years ago, five years ago or at any time in the past that anyone would have to be very careful about travelling to any function or making telephone calls because of the expense? Of course, home entertainment is also a problem, as most people have access to only the ABC and, in some cases if they are lucky, one commercial television station. Because of this government's policies—or, more to the point, the lack of compassion in its policies—many of these women who have always contributed so much to their community and society say they are feeling more isolated and confined to their homes.

The lack of social contact outside of the home compounds the problems of isolation. This long rural recession has led to the amalgamation of many clubs—sporting clubs, football clubs, netball clubs and so on—and has forced the closure of many social activities. The reasons are quite apparent. Many people just cannot afford club memberships. As low as those fees may be in many rural areas, people cannot afford to belong to organisations. Many families, including parents and young children at times, have to work longer hours on the farm and cannot afford to employ outside help. Then there are the people who are packing up and moving into the cities to try to find jobs and who join the increasing number of job market queues.

What is even sadder is the fact that volunteer organisations have felt the effect of this decline. Many of those organisations also have had to reduce—in some cases cut—essential community services. Nowhere have volunteer organisations been more to the fore than in most of the country areas and rural communities throughout Australia. I am sure that Senator Cooney knows of many in Victoria and certainly there are many in my own state of South Australia. The situation is catastrophic because volunteers have been an integral part of almost every community and the services they provide have been of great value—not only in terms of the services themselves but because of the social impact of those volunteer groups. Many rural people are feeling the impact of this loss.

The lives of many rural Australians are not easy and nothing in this budget has made life any easier for them. In my home state of South Australia the rural debt crisis has caused such hardship to a number of families that the state government commissioned an audit into this crisis. That government emphasised that it had a great concern for:

SPEECH.PARA: South Australia to retain its tradition of strong rural communities with the family farm as the basic unit.

The sad fact is that the federal government does not appear to have the same commitment to those farming families. South Australian farmers produce up to 50 per cent of the state's exports. A report from a rural counsellor in my area indicates that some farmers are in a catch-22 situation. Some farmers in need of quick cash are selling their farm machinery at discount or fire sale prices much below market value in order to get cash. In the long run this only impedes their ability to produce and return to a profit.

PARA.TAB: In this budget the government had the opportunity to extend the investment allowance to provide tax breaks on new investments and plant equipment. Groups such as the National Farmers' Federation urged the government to show some compassion and extend the allowance to help farms remain viable. Very simply, this extension may have stimulated real job growth in rural related industries. Unfortunately, this government prefers to be a big spender in other areas. It has chosen instead to spend millions of dollars to provide trainee positions for what may or may not ever evolve into real jobs. It is too bad about keeping those in jobs that already have them but much of the spending on traineeships may never mean jobs. This and many other of this government's short-sighted policies have shown nothing but contempt for some of the battlers in the country.

The audit into the level of rural debt in South Australia revealed that although many farmers are in need of some government assistance, their situation is not hopeless. The audit pointed out that 77 per cent of all farm businesses were shown to be viable and five per cent, or just over 650 farms, are non-viable and face the possibility of closure. Overall the report was encouraging and showed that with some Commonwealth assistance farmers stood a strong chance of pulling themselves out of this tough recession.

Why has the federal government not done more to try to maintain the existence of these export earning producers—especially since they have an excellent chance of remaining viable and contributing to the economy? This government should not be putting obstacles in their way but making it possible for them to return to viability.

I also wish to refer to a study conducted by South Australia's parliamentary committee on social development. That committee found that the state's rural crisis has had a profound psychological impact on 23 per cent of farming families who are undergoing severe financial hardship.

It has been reported in the Murray-Mallee region of the state that some children are blaming themselves for their parents' financial problems and are asking school counsellors how they can be adopted out of the family home. I think it is a tragedy that in a country such as Australia such a thing can happen. Stories about hungry children being forced to steal food was front page news, but one would have to wonder whether the Prime Minister or members of his government even know or understand the depths of despair reached by some families in rural Australia. To stand by and allow this to happen in our society is disgraceful.

How can the federal government tolerate this? Where is the social justice that is so often talked about by this government? I find the hypocrisy within the Keating government even more appalling when we hear about its outspoken stand against human rights abuses overseas when at the same time that government allows hardship and social injustice to foster right under its nose.

I certainly believe that Australia should participate in defeating human rights abuses overseas, but there is no justification for turning a blind eye to similar problems in our own backyard. The tragedies of youth suicide, hunger, isolation and lack of basic services are not alleviated by insensitive government policies, particularly in this budget.

The much vaunted Kelty report on regional development recommends that all Australians be given equal access to basic services such as education, transport, communications, health and community services. It has also recommended that:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . regions suffering some specific disadvantage, for example their remoteness, should have access to special assistance.

I can only concur that in some areas that should be the case. But as long as this government remains in office it seems as though nothing will change and that life will only get tougher for rural people.

PARA.TAB: The federal government has proven time and again that it is completely out of touch with average Australians, and particularly those who happen to live outside metropolitan areas. I challenge both the Prime Minister and the Treasurer to spend even just a few days with a struggling farm family in the Murray-Mallee region or on Eyre Peninsula. I cannot imagine that they will ever take me up on this challenge, but I will make it anyway. If only they could experience for just a few days the hardships that these families face every day. I am certain that if the Prime Minister and the Treasurer (Mr Willis) saw at first hand what it is really like to live under their policies—particularly the lack of concern shown in this budget and preceding budgets—only then might they finally have some compassion for those Australian families living outside the metropolitan areas who are battling all the odds to try to earn a living for themselves and to earn export dollars for Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz Sen E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the appropriations debate, with real concern as to what this Labor government is doing to my state of Tasmania and my country Australia, and indeed what it has been doing since 1983. I also want to take this opportunity to expand upon comments that I made in my first speech in this chamber about Commonwealth-state funding relationships.

PARA.TAB: The 1994-95 budget tax implications have caused me a great deal of concern. I am concerned because this labor government has not been able to keep promises pledged to the Australian electorate. Even those taxation promises which the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) said were legislated—in other words, L-A-W, law—have now been broken. How does this Labor government explain the estimated tax revenue increase of $9.154 billion from 1993-94 to this financial year? That is the increase in just a year. How does this Labor government explain the 1994-95 tax revenue of $103.3 billion? The last budget delivered by the Fraser government on 17 August 1982 provided for that year estimated tax revenue of $41.8 billion. The estimated tax revenue for 1994-95 is $103.3 billion. This represents almost 2 1/2 times as much. The saying is true—`Labor equals high taxes', thus reducing individual choice. How does the Labor government explain the real tax revenue increase of 7.4 per cent between 1993-94 and 1994-95?

Paul Keating told our fellow Australians that the tax decreases were already law: l-a-w. The deceit and dishonesty of this government appears to know no bounds. Labor taxes ordinary Australians and businesses to the hilt to cover up its mismanagement and incompetent handling of the Australian economy.

Despite the increase in taxation under this government, we have not seen the gap between rich and poor diminish. Indeed, the gap between rich and poor is widening. The unemployment problem facing this country has not been addressed. Unemployment queues did not decrease with the One Nation package and I seriously doubt whether the current white paper will make a dent in these queues. Sure, we will see a fluctuation from time to time, but to hear Senator Schacht tell us during question time today that an unemployment rate of 9 per cent plus is good news is appalling. It is like saying to the Australian people, `You ought to be thankful that it is not 10 or 20 per cent; that 10 or 20 per cent of you aren't unemployed.' The so-called reduction, in fact, is only a reduction from the Labor-created, all-time high.

I now seek to deal with the role of states and territories vis-a-vis the Commonwealth and service delivery. Traditionally, the states and territories have played a major role in the provision of public services in Australia. In fact, the states own purpose outlays represent about 45 per cent of total public sector outlays. The present allocation of tax powers in the Australian Federation means that the states and territories cannot efficiently and equitably fund these expenditures from their own revenues. State expenditure responsibilities substantially exceed their revenues. The reverse applies for the Commonwealth government.

The trend over recent years not to reduce the impact of the so-called vertical fiscal imbalance by increasing state funding through general purpose grants has worsened the impact on the states. For people like me who cannot grasp the economic jargon `vertical fiscal imbalance', it means the people who raise most of the money do not spend it, namely, the federal government, and the people who do most of the spending do not raise it, namely, the state and territory governments. State government outlays are concentrated in areas of direct and real service provision, such as education, hospitals, police, and public transport. Commonwealth outlays are dominated by transfer payments such as pensions.

The different role of Commonwealth and state outlays has important implications for financial relations between the Commonwealth and the states and, therefore, our Federation. While it can be argued that productivity savings are possible in state outlays, the same can also be said for Commonwealth outlays. We must also recognise that demand for state services rises with inflation, population growth and community expectations associated with any rise in living standards. The Commonwealth tax base reflects the changes in economic activity, including inflation and changes in population. State tax bases are less responsive to these trends and are more responsive to asset price fluctuations.

As a senator with the honour of representing Tasmania, I am fully aware of the impact that Commonwealth-state financial relations have had on my state. Some of the concerns which need to be raised include: the extent of cutbacks in Commonwealth payments; the continual changes to funding arrangements since the termination of the revenue sharing arrangement in 1984-85—naturally, this extends to the on-going uncertainty regarding Commonwealth funding to the states from 1994-95 onwards; and the increasing intrusiveness of the Commonwealth government through the use of tied grants in expenditure areas which should be undertaken at the state level.

When the Commonwealth government took over responsibility for income tax powers during World War II, the Commonwealth agreed to provide general purpose grants to the states as compensation. In fact, if we refer to Mr Chifley's second reading speech on the States Grants (Income Reimbursement) Bill 1942, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has undertaken to make to each State agreeing to that response a grant of financial assistance to compensate for the income tax revenue lost to the State . . .
He went on to say—and this is the vital point that needs to be grasped by this centralist government:

In the proposed grant, the Government has approached the problem reasonably and even generously so that no charge of interference with normal State functions can be seriously put forward by those opposed to the plan for a single taxing authority.

It is pity that this current Labor government, which seeks to eulogise Chifley, pays no attention to the words of Ben Chifley in 1942. I repeat what he said: `No charge of interference with normal state functions.' I will outline more of that later.

PARA.TAB: Since that time, these grants have been calculated on a number of bases ranging from ad hoc percentage increases to a fixed proportion of a subset of Commonwealth revenues. From 1984-85, under this Labor government Commonwealth payments to the states have generally been determined on an even more ad hoc basis. The exception has been that the Commonwealth guaranteed to maintain the total level of financial assistance grants in real terms over the period 1991-92 and 1993-94.

The current level of financial assistance grants to the six states as a proportion tax revenues has substantially declined over the past 20 years. Financial assistance grants are moneys paid in general revenue and can be spent at the discretion of the state or territory government concerned. For example, 1976-77 to 1984-85 financial assistance grants as a percentage of Commonwealth tax revenue stood at 18.9 per cent based on revenue sharing arrangements. Comparable figures adjusted on a compatible basis with the earlier period show that for 1993-94 this has fallen to 14.6 per cent—a substantial decrease and part of Labor's campaign of destroying our federal system and bleeding the states white. Data indicates that in monetary terms there has been a cutback in the level of general revenue payments of $4 billion compared to the average level under the revenue sharing arrangements. How much is $4 billion? It is like winning $1 million every day for the next 4,000 days or for the next 10 years. That is a huge amount in anybody's language.

While the level of financial assistance grants has fallen significantly, the reverse is true for the level of tied grants. Tied grants are federal moneys given to the states and territories to be used only for specific programs. They are generally known as specific purpose payments. Tied grants go to programs such as housing initiatives under the Commonwealth-state housing agreement and disability programs under the Commonwealth-state disability agreement.

Compared with the period 1976-77 to 1984-85, the proportion of funds in the form of tied grants has increased significantly from 32.4 per cent to 43 per cent in 1993-94. In dollar terms, the increase in specific purpose payments between 1976-77 and 1984-85 was in the order of $235 million. Over the period from 1976-77 to 1993-94, tied grants initially decreased as a share of total Commonwealth tax outlays. However, from 1982-83 they have increased rapidly under Labor. When the Fraser government came to power in 1976 we saw a decrease in the number of tied grants. The Liberal government upheld the spirit of cooperative federalism between the Commonwealth and state governments. From 1983, when Labor came to office, the situation reverted and has got progressively worse. It says a lot about the spending priorities of this Labor government. Instead of concentrating on federal funding issues, the Labor government spends its time and energy pulling state and territory government purse strings. So much for the so-called `no charge of interference with normal state functions' which Ben Chifley, the Labor Prime Minister, advocated in 1942. So much for Paul Keating and the Australian Labor Party seeking to eulogise Ben Chifley. It is just further proof that Labor's rhetoric is not matched by its actions.

At the end of the day, these budget figures, as figures, are not very exciting but their implication for our unique federal system of government is horrific. Funding for specific grants, as opposed to general purpose grants, does not mean very much to the average Australian by way of terminology. However, what is relevant is the impact this type of funding has had on the states and territories.

States like Tasmania have suffered under the impact of the growth in tied grants. Tied grants give the federal government leverage to get the priorities on service delivery that it wants implemented in the states, irrespective of the priorities set by the democratically elected state government. In typical Labor centralist style it believes that, out of its glass house in recession-proof Canberra, it is able to determine Tasmania's needs and accordingly dictate Tasmania's priorities.

Tied grants do not allow state governments to exercise their own independent judgment based on local knowledge and an understanding of the aspirations of their residents. Surely state governments, with their local knowledge and capacity to be responsive, should determine the priorities for delivery of services to target those in most need.

Tied grants restrict the fiscal flexibility of the states to provide the necessary targeted services that state governments are responsible for providing. It is just like having a financial gun barrel held to the head of state governments. Indeed, this Labor government is nothing better than an assassin of our country, our flag and our unique and dynamic federal system of government.

State governments are on the ground. They are close to the people who need day-to-day services such as hospitals, schools and other essential services. In fact, state governments are closer to the people than Canberra-based bureaucracies and deliver the day-to-day services that are required more efficiently, equitably and flexibly and know which services are a priority.

Under this federal Labor government, tied grants have meant that state governments have not been able to determine priorities because their hands have been tied behind their backs. This centralist federal Labor government has sought to make political eunuchs of the state governments. Not only does it deny states from exercising their right to set priorities, it also seeks to dictate their domestic laws based on spurious decisions.

Indeed, centralism under Labor is now going from the states to Canberra. And if that were not bad enough, Labor now takes it from Canberra to Geneva. Labor is centralism gone mad. The dominance of specific purpose payments has continued despite the endorsed objective of the October 1990 Special Premiers Conference to reduce the level of tied payments to that of the 1980s.

Another consequence of the prevalence of tied payments is the costly duplication and overlap between Commonwealth and state service delivery. Over the past ten years there has been an increasing concentration of Commonwealth expenditure in areas of traditional state responsibility, such as education and health. At the same time, state and territory governments are undertaking functions that have traditionally fallen within the realms of Commonwealth responsibility—for example, income support and public rental housing assistance.

The figures I have outlined today indicate that since 1984-85, when formal revenue sharing arrangements ended, the approach to Commonwealth-state financial arrangements has substantially disadvantaged the states. This is especially the case in small states like Tasmania.

Measured against the benchmark data outlined earlier, financial assistance grants to the state and territory governments as a share of total Commonwealth tax have declined by $4 billion. The offset has been a $235 million increase in specific purpose grants to the state governments. This equates to a total net loss to the states of $3.765 billion. The states are paying very dearly for the federal government's overseas debt and gross mismanagement of the economy.

And what about our debt? It is currently running at $164 billion! That is about $10,000 for every man, woman and child in Australia—approximately $10,000 worth of debt for every Australian. There is no social justice in living it up now at the expense of our children. This Labor government is mortgaging Australia's future and my children's future.

On top of this chronic debt we have chronic unemployment. Without the debt, how chronic would our unemployment really be? Fundamental structural problems are facing my country and I despair at the duplicity of commentators and of this Labor government in refusing to acknowledge these gigantic problems.

I have noted with interest the emerging battle in cabinet and caucus over the plan to reduce the proportion of specific purpose grants to the states. There appears to be a bun fight looming over this whole issue—a further indication that Labor has lost the plot. These Labor ministers should take themselves out of their airconditioned offices and limousines in Canberra and get amongst the real world.

Back in the states and territories, the electorate is saying, `We want genuine service delivery. We want accountable service delivery. We want value for our taxes.' Hardworking Australians do not want to hear that their taxes are being hurriedly `tied up' by ministers in Canberra, as one journalist put it in the Canberra Times of 8 June. Nor do they want to hear and read that ministers are arranging new tied funding for specific programs with the states to protect their own ministerial portfolio funding power game in Canberra.

Ministerial power games in Canberra do not deliver services to my fellow Australians; genuine concern, cooperate federalism and local decision making will. The Australian community deserves much more from their elected representatives, particularly those who make up the federal Labor ministry.

In the light of the data I have put before the chamber today, the federal government should look seriously at redressing the imbalance in Commonwealth-state funding arrangements.
